titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Hosmer Penniman Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled and edited by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Contains correspondence of James Hosmer Penniman, teacher, educator, and literary and historical collector. The rest of the papers consist of Penniman's collection of historical documents, correspondence, diaries, manuscripts, other papers and books on the subject of education. Included here is a discrete collection of David Francis Lincoln (1841-1916) papers containing correspondence and research notes on Lincoln's studies on various aspects of education.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Hosmer Penniman Collection (MS 9). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of James H. Penniman, 1921-1926, and of the Penniman family, 1931.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: I. Correspondence. II. Subject Files. III. Legal Papers. IV. Educational Materials. V. David Francis Lincoln. VI. Engravings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The James Hosmer Penniman Collection consists of three separately acquired groups: personal papers of Penniman; manuscripts relating to education and American history collected by Mr. Penniman and given to the Yale University Library from 1921 through 1926; and materials acquired from various sources relating to education which were added to the collection after his death as part of the Penniman Memorial Library of Education.

James Hosmer Penniman (1860-1931) graduated from Yale in 1884. Yale relatives whose papers are also at Yale include James Lanman (B.A. 1788), Matthew and Roger Griswold (both B.A. 1780), and Charles J. Lanman (B.A. 1814). After 28 years as a teacher and administrator of the Lower School of the DeLancey School, Philadelphia, Mr. Penniman retired in 1913 and devoted the remainder of his life to literary pursuits and travel. He founded the Maria Hosmer Penniman Memorial Library of Education at the University of Pennsylvania (1915), the Penniman Memorial Library of Education at Brown (1921) and the Penniman Memorial Library of Education at Yale (1920). To the volumes on education already in the university library, Dr. Penniman added books, magazines, and reports, and rare books and manuscripts as the opportunity offered. He gave to the Library more than 4000 books and 1000 pamphlets, and from funds provided by him more than 6200 volumes were purchased up to the time of his death. To maintain and increase the library, he endowed a fund of $50,000 in 1927.

In addition to his interest in libraries and education, Mr. Penniman was an internationally known authority on George Washington and the early history of the United States and a collector of Washingtoniana. Some of the manuscripts in the collection relate to the preparation of many of his books which included: Common Words Difficult To Spell (1891), Practical Suggestions In School Government (1899), Books And How To Make The Most Of Them (1910), George Washington As Commander In Chief (1917), George Washington As Man Of Letters (1918), George Washington At Mount Vernon (1921), Our Debt To France (1921), What Lafayette Did For America (1921), Philadelphia In The Early Eighteen Hundreds (1923).

At the time of his death, he had largely completed a two-volume work on George Washington. Some of the letters relate to his proposal to build the "Highway of the Thirteen Original States," from Washington to Mount Vernon.

In August, 1982, an autograph book, kept ca. 1875-1882 by James H. Penniman, was added to the collection. Because of the value of some of the autographs (e.g., Presidents Grant and Hayes), this item has been placed in the Security File.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Teacher and administrator of the Lower School of the DeLancey School, Philadelphia (1885-1913); founded Maria Hosmer Penniman Memorial Library of Education at the University of Pennsylvania (1915), Penniman Memorial Library of Education at Brown (1921), Penniman Memorial Library of Education at Yale (1920); author on George Washington and the early United States, and collector of Washingtoniana.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is divided into two sections. The first section includes letters, postcards, and telegrams as well as newspaper clippings, miniature water colors and envelopes received by J.H. Penniman. These relate to his personal and professional activities which include the founding of a number of memorial libraries, the proposal of his highway plan, various publishing endeavors and his involvement in education. Correspondence in this section is arranged alphabetically by author and then chronologically for each author. Individual correspondents include Theodore Roosevelt, James Rowland Angell and John Grier Hibben.

The second section is comprised of collected correspondence, newspaper clippings and autographs of other individuals including many eminent American and European historical figures, men associated with educational institutions and graduates of Yale University. Biographical information has been added to a considerable portion of the material. This section of correspondence is arranged alphabetically by author and then by addressee for each author. Individual correspondents include Aba-el-Kadu, Cardinal Alteri, the Duke of Argyll, Aaron Burr, John C. Calhoun, Henry Clay, Paul Du Chaillu, William E. Gladstone, Sir William Hamilton, Kalakana Rex, Lord Lyttledon, Alfred Thayer Mahan, Rembrandt Peale, Jonathan Trumbull, Daniel Webster.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains articles relating to education as well as manuscripts of poems, a play and a Latin dictionary. Included also are autographs, an autograph book, a diary and some personal materials of J.H. Penniman.
The Subject File is arranged alphabetically by subject or author.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains various legal documents pertaining to the American colonies and the early national period. These include warrants of arrest, bills, receipts, deeds, shareholder's certificates, the probate of a will, the transcript of a trial and an attorney's case. Also included is a letter of introduction from Metternich and a passport for traveling in France. Biographical information has been added to much of the material. Series III is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV is divided into two sections. The first section contains documents of various schools. These include petitions, charters, reports and certificates given to students. These documents are arranged chronologically with undated material at the end.

The second section, "Books," includes textbooks, notebooks (mostly arithmetic notebooks) and study materials such as penmanship sheets. Also included is an Italian teaching manual. The books are arranged alphabetically by type. Within each type-category, they are arranged in chronological order with undated material at the end. The owner's names are also indicated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is a miniature collection of materials relating to David Francis Lincoln's research and theories on education as well as problems of education in general. It is divided into three sections.

The first section, "Correspondence," includes professional correspondence of D.F. Lincoln which largely concerns his theory of the "Half-time System" and descriptions of different school systems. Enclosed also are school infirmary charts and a report to the Board of Education. Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by author and then by recipient for each author.

The second section includes Lincoln's notes on the "Half-time System," German and English schools and other aspects of education. The notes are arranged alphabetically by assigned subject titles. Excerpts and quotes are designated by the term "from" which precedes the name of the source.
The third section includes manuscripts of two essays on education by Mr. Lincoln.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes a cartoon, engravings and photographs of men whose correspondence are included in Series I. Engravings are entered alphabetically under the name of the individual pictured.
